Protein–Protein Interaction (PPI) Prediction Methods Summary Preface

Protein–Protein Interaction (PPI) Prediction Methods Summary Haoyi Yang 2025-11-24 Preface Notes repository (GitHub)：https://github.com/HayesYoung58/PPI_Prediction_Methods_Summary This study note is a summary of computational methods for Protein–Protein Interaction (PPI) prediction. Its goal is to organize existing tools, prediction paradigms, and representative models into clear methodological categories, enabling both beginners and researchers to quickly understand the landscape of PPI analysis. The content is divided into five methodological categories: Docking-based methods Structure-based analysis and interface evaluation Sequence / knowledge–based prediction methods Deep learning–based approaches Structure-generation frameworks such as AlphaFold-Multimer Each chapter introduces the theory, representative tools, strengths, weaknesses, and practical usage suggestions. This note was written using Rmarkdown. Thanks to Yihui Xie and others for providing the template. Reference - Allaire, JJ, Yihui Xie, Christophe Dervieux, Jonathan McPherson, Javier Luraschi, Kevin Ushey, Aron Atkins, et al. 2023. Chapter 1 Introduction to Protein–Protein Interaction (PPI) Prediction Protein–protein interactions (PPIs) are central to almost all biological processes, including signal transduction, metabolic regulation, transcriptional control, immune responses, and complex assembly. Understanding and predicting PPIs is therefore fundamental in fields such as structural biology, molecular biophysics, drug discovery, and systems biology. Experimental techniques—such as Yeast Two-Hybrid (Y2H), Co-immunoprecipitation (Co-IP), affinity purification–mass spectrometry (AP–MS), and cross-linking MS—provide powerful ways to detect interactions, but these approaches can be costly, low-throughput, or limited in coverage. As a result, computational prediction of PPIs has become essential for large-scale screening and mechanistic understanding. This chapter provides an overview of the main computational paradigms used in PPI prediction and outlines their conceptual differences, input requirements, and typical applications. 1.1 Why Computational PPI Prediction Matters Computational models help address several limitations of experimental methods: High throughput: Predict interactions at the proteome scale. Low cost: Reduce the need for extensive wet-lab screening. Hypothesis generation: Identify candidates for validation. Structural insight: Predict binding interfaces and complex conformations. Integration of diverse data sources: Combine sequence, structure, evolution, and literature. Computational predictions are especially useful when: structural data is incomplete, experimental conditions are difficult to mimic, high-throughput screening is required (e.g., drug target identification), or evolution-based insights can reveal conserved interaction patterns. 1.2 Categories of Computational PPI Prediction Methods Current computational approaches to PPI prediction can be broadly divided into five major categories, each with different assumptions, data dependencies, and output types. These categories correspond to Chapters 2–6 of this book. 1. Docking-Based (Structure-Based) Methods Use 3D protein structures as input and generate possible complex conformations using: rigid-body or flexible-body docking energy scoring interface restraints Representative tools: HADDOCK, HDOCK, ClusPro, ZDOCK, GRAMM, pyDock These methods aim to predict how two proteins bind (binding mode). 2. Structure-Based Interface Analysis These methods evaluate existing protein complexes to determine whether: the interface is physically realistic, the complex is biologically meaningful, the interaction is stable. Representative tool: PDBePISA Often used after docking or AlphaFold-Multimer predictions. 3. Sequence / Knowledge–Based Prediction These models rely on: amino acid sequences evolutionary co-variation protein domains biological networks literature mining Representative tools: STRING, PrePPI, PPI-Miner, COTH These methods answer whether two proteins might interact, but rarely predict complex geometry. 4. Deep Learning–Based PPI Prediction End-to-end neural architectures that use learned representations (embeddings) from: Transformers protein language models (e.g., ESM, ProtBERT) graph neural networks (GNNs) Representative tools/models: D-SCRIPT, DeepPurpose (PPI module), MAPE-PPI These approaches can capture subtle patterns beyond handcrafted features. 5. Structure Generation Approaches These methods directly generate complex structures from sequence inputs. Representative model: AlphaFold-Multimer Features: predicts complex geometry outputs confidence metrics (pLDDT, ipTM, pTM) can be combined with docking-based refinement or interface scoring This paradigm is increasingly used in structural proteomics and binder engineering. 1.3 When to Use Each Category Question Recommended Methods “Do A and B likely interact?” STRING, PrePPI, D-SCRIPT, DeepPurpose “What might the interface look like?” Docking tools (HADDOCK, ClusPro, HDOCK) “Is this predicted complex stable?” PDBePISA “Can we generate a complex structure directly from sequence?” AlphaFold-Multimer “I want large-scale computational screening.” Sequence-based + Deep Learning models This book organizes the chapters according to this logic. 1.4 Structure of This Book Chapter 2 — Docking-based prediction tools Chapter 3 — Structure-based interface and complex evaluation Chapter 4 — Sequence-/knowledge-based prediction models Chapter 5 — Deep learning–based models Chapter 6 — Structure-generation approaches such as AlphaFold-Multimer Chapter 7 — References & resources Each chapter contains: theoretical overview representative tools comparison tables input/output format strengths & weaknesses practical tips for using each tool 1.5 Suggested Reading Recommended reviews and references will be collected in Chapter 7.

Chapter 2 Docking-Based (Structure-Based) PPI Prediction 2.1 Overview of Docking Approaches 2.2 HADDOCK 2.3 HDOCK Server 2.4 ClusPro 2.5 ZDOCK 2.6 GRAMM (Vakser Lab) 2.7 pyDock 2.8 Comparative Summary of Docking Tools 2.9 Practical Workflow Suggestions 2.10 Relation to Other Chapters

Chapter 2 Docking-Based (Structure-Based) PPI Prediction Computational docking methods aim to predict how two proteins interact by generating possible 3D complex structures (binding poses). These approaches rely on physical or statistical scoring functions and often explore a large search space of relative orientations between proteins. Docking methods are particularly useful when: structures of individual monomers are available the interface is unknown experimental structural data is limited refinement of predicted complexes is needed validating interactions suggested by sequence-based models This chapter summarizes six widely used protein–protein docking tools: HADDOCK, HDOCK Server, ClusPro, ZDOCK, GRAMM, and pyDock. 2.1 Overview of Docking Approaches Docking methods typically follow three major steps: 2.1.1. Sampling {-} Explore relative orientations and positions of the two proteins (rigid-body, soft-body, flexible docking). 2.1.2. Scoring {-} Evaluate poses using: - van der Waals energy - electrostatics - desolvation - empirical potentials - knowledge-based scores - constraint penalties 2.1.3. Clustering & Ranking {-} Group similar poses and rank clusters based on energy or cluster size. Docking approaches can be further categorized as: Rigid-body docking (ZDOCK, GRAMM) Flexible docking (HADDOCK) Template-based docking (HDOCK) Scoring-only workflows (pyDock) 2.2 HADDOCK HADDOCK (High Ambiguity Driven biomolecular DOCKing) A powerful data-driven docking platform that integrates experimental or predicted interface restraints. Key Features Incorporates experimental data (NMR, mutagenesis, cryo-EM) Supports flexible docking via simulated annealing Multi-body docking Highly customizable scoring function Input PDB structures Optional ambiguous interaction restraints (AIRs) Output Top-ranked clusters Complex structures Energy breakdown (van der Waals, electrostatics, restraints) Advantages Most accurate when interface information is available Suitable for refinement Limitations Slower than rigid docking Requires more parameter tuning 2.3 HDOCK Server A hybrid approach combining template-based docking and free docking. Key Features Accepts protein sequences or structures Automatically searches templates for homologous complexes Also performs ab initio docking if no template is found Fully automated server Input PDB or FASTA sequences Optional binding site specification Output Docking models Template matches Scoring based on statistical + physics potentials Advantages Extremely user-friendly Good performance when templates are available Limitations Template quality affects results 2.4 ClusPro A classic and widely used rigid-body docking method. Key Features Uses PIPER docking engine Clusters docking poses based on RMSD Ranks by cluster population Supports antibody–antigen docking mode Input Two protein structures Output Top 10–30 docking models Cluster energy Population size Advantages Very stable performance Good for easy-to-medium difficulty targets Limitations Rigid-body only No direct flexibility modeling 2.5 ZDOCK A fast and robust FFT-based docking engine. Key Features Rigid-body search in 3D rotational space Uses shape complementarity + electrostatics Extremely fast for proteome-scale screening Input Two PDB structures Output Ranked list of binding orientations ZDOCK score Advantages Very fast Good initial docking poses Limitations No flexibility May require post-processing refinement 2.6 GRAMM (Vakser Lab) GRAMM uses coarse-grained grid matching for global docking. Key Features Grid-based low-resolution matching Soft potentials for faster search Good for initial screening Input PDB files Output Low-resolution docking models Advantages Ultra-fast Good for generating initial poses Limitations Lower resolution Usually requires refinement 2.7 pyDock pyDock is primarily a scoring function, not a docking engine. Key Features Electrostatics + desolvation scoring Can rescore models from ZDOCK, ClusPro, HADDOCK Very useful for reranking low-energy poses Input Complex structures (PDB) Output pyDock energy score Ranked poses Advantages Excellent for refinement Improves accuracy of rigid docking Limitations Cannot generate docking poses itself 2.8 Comparative Summary of Docking Tools Below is a comparison table that summarizes core differences. Tool Docking Type Accepts Sequence? Flexibility Template-based? Speed Best Use Case HADDOCK Flexible No ★★★★☆ Optional Slow Accurate docking with restraints HDOCK Hybrid Yes ★★☆☆☆ Yes Medium Mixed template + free docking ClusPro Rigid No ★☆☆☆☆ No Medium Stable general docking ZDOCK Rigid No ★☆☆☆☆ No Fast High-throughput rigid docking GRAMM Rigid (low-res) No ★☆☆☆☆ No Very fast Coarse screening pyDock Scoring only No N/A No Fast Rescoring/refinement 2.9 Practical Workflow Suggestions When starting without structural information Predict monomer structures (e.g., AlphaFold2, ESMFold) Use ZDOCK or HDOCK for quick rigid docking Refine top poses using HADDOCK Evaluate stability using PDBePISA When interface residues are known or predicted Use HADDOCK with restraints Evaluate clusters and perform flexible refinement When many protein pairs must be screened Use ZDOCK or GRAMM for initial docking Rescore top poses using pyDock When sequences are available but structures are missing HDOCK (sequence input allowed) Or predict structures first → docking 2.10 Relation to Other Chapters Structure analysis tools such as PDBePISA (Chapter 3) can validate docking results. Sequence-based and deep learning models (Chapters 4–5) can provide interaction candidates before docking. Structure-generation tools like AlphaFold-Multimer (Chapter 6) may replace docking in some cases but still benefit from refinement.

Chapter 3 Structure-Based Interface Analysis (PDBePISA) 3.1 Purpose of Structure-Based Interface Analysis 3.2 What Is PDBePISA? 3.3 How PDBePISA Works 3.4 Key Outputs of PDBePISA 3.5 When to Use PDBePISA 3.6 PDBePISA vs. Docking Scores 3.7 Practical Workflow Integration 3.8 Advantages and Limitations 3.9 Summary

Chapter 3 Structure-Based Interface Analysis (PDBePISA) Structure-based interface analysis focuses on evaluating whether a predicted or experimentally determined protein complex is physically meaningful and biologically relevant. Among all available tools, PDBePISA is the most widely used platform for analyzing macromolecular interfaces, assemblies, and stability. This chapter summarizes the principles, metrics, and practical applications of PDBePISA in protein–protein interaction (PPI) studies. 3.1 Purpose of Structure-Based Interface Analysis Docking methods (Chapter 2) can generate thousands of possible binding orientations. Structure analysis tools—such as PDBePISA—help answer critical questions: Is the predicted interface thermodynamically stable? Is the interaction likely to occur in solution, not just in the crystal? What is the interface area, buried surface, or energetic contributions? Which residues form the interface? Are the hydrogen bonds, salt bridges, and hydrophobic contacts plausible? Does the complex appear to be a biologically relevant assembly? Thus, PDBePISA is a validation and interpretation tool for structural models, whether derived from: docking AlphaFold-Multimer cryo-EM crystallography NMR 3.2 What Is PDBePISA? PDBePISA (Protein Interfaces, Surfaces & Assemblies) is a web server developed by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI) for: calculating macromolecular interfaces analyzing biological assemblies estimating thermodynamic stability identifying interface residues, contacts, and networks PISA operates on atomic-level structures from PDB or user-uploaded models. Website: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/pdbe/pisa/ 3.3 How PDBePISA Works PISA evaluates protein–protein interfaces using: 1. Buried Surface Area (BSA) The area lost upon complex formation (Å²). Large BSA values (≥ 1,000–2,000 Å²) typically indicate stable interfaces. 2. Solvation Free Energy Gain (ΔGint) Estimates the free energy change associated with interface formation. Negative values → stable interaction More negative = stronger predicted interaction 3. Hydrogen Bond and Salt Bridge Networks PISA identifies: H-bonds (distance + angle criteria) salt bridges (charged side-chain interactions) hydrophobic patches 4. Interface Residue Mapping Provides detailed residue-level interactions, including: donor/acceptor atoms contact distances contributing side chains 5. Biological Assembly Prediction PISA distinguishes between: biologically relevant interfaces crystallographic artifacts (crystal contacts) based on thermodynamic scoring and symmetry analysis. 3.4 Key Outputs of PDBePISA When a structure is analyzed, PISA provides: • Interface Summary Interface area Solvation energy Number of hydrogen bonds Number of salt bridges Hydrophobic contacts • Assembly Summary Predicted quaternary structures (e.g., dimer, trimer, tetramer). • Stability Prediction Includes: ΔGdiss — estimated dissociation free energy Complex stability score A positive ΔGdiss indicates the complex is stable in solution. • Detailed Contact Map Residue-by-residue interface interactions, useful for: mutagenesis design engineering hotspot identification cross-model comparison 3.5 When to Use PDBePISA PDBePISA is useful in the following scenarios: 1. After Docking (Chapter 2) To validate whether docking poses are: physically reasonable likely stable in solution consistent with known interaction patterns 2. After AlphaFold-Multimer Prediction (Chapter 6) AlphaFold often predicts multimers, but not all interfaces are realistic. Use PISA to check: interface area ΔGint hydrogen bond network potential crystal-like contacts multimer assembly correctness 3. Crystal Structure Interpretation To determine if biological assemblies differ from PDB’s asymmetric unit. 4. Identifying Potential Hotspots Residues with strong contributions to binding energy can be used for: mutagenesis binder design inhibitor development 3.6 PDBePISA vs. Docking Scores Metric Docking Tools PDBePISA Purpose Ranking poses Validating physicochemical plausibility Type Empirical/physics scoring Thermodynamic + geometric analysis Outputs Pose score, clusters ΔGint, ΔGdiss, BSA, residue interactions Sensitivity Sensitive to scoring function Sensitive to interface geometry Best used for Pose selection Biological relevance evaluation Docking answers: “Which orientation seems best?” PISA answers: “Is this orientation stable and realistic?” 3.7 Practical Workflow Integration A recommended pipeline integrating Chapter 2 and 3: Generate monomer structures AlphaFold2 / ESMFold / experimental structures Initial docking ZDOCK / HDOCK / ClusPro to generate large pose sets Refinement HADDOCK / RosettaDock / AlphaFold-Multimer Interface analysis using PISA Confirm interface area size Check ΔGint sign Check the number of H-bonds / salt bridges Ensure plausible packing geometry Ranking + filtering Combine docking score + PISA metrics Experimental design Use interface hotspots to design mutations for validation 3.8 Advantages and Limitations Advantages Provides residue-level and energy-based insight Distinguishes real interfaces from crystal artifacts Applicable to any structural model Very intuitive visualization Limitations Requires accurate atomic coordinates Does not generate poses (not a docking tool) Energetics are approximate, not true MD/DFT energies Sensitive to model quality (garbage-in → garbage-out) 3.9 Summary PDBePISA is an essential tool for validating and interpreting PPI structural models. It complements the docking methods described in Chapter 2 and the structure-generation models of Chapter 6. In typical workflows, PISA is used to: assess interface stability evaluate docking poses validate AlphaFold-Multimer complexes identify interface residues explore biological assemblies This makes it one of the most valuable and reliable tools for structure-based PPI analysis.

Chapter 4 Sequence- and Knowledge-Based PPI Prediction Models Sequence- and knowledge-based PPI prediction methods rely on evolutionary, functional, domain, or literature-derived information rather than 3D structural data. These approaches are particularly useful when protein structures are unavailable, or when large-scale network inference is required. This chapter summarizes four widely used resources and models: STRING PrePPI PPI-Miner COTH Together, they represent the major paradigms for sequence-level and knowledge-driven PPI prediction. 4.1 Overview of Sequence / Knowledge-Based Methods Unlike docking or structural analysis (Chapters 2–3), sequence- and knowledge-based approaches aim to answer: “Do protein A and B interact?” (Without predicting how they bind.) These methods make use of one or more of the following information sources: 4.1.1. Evolutionary Features Orthology Co-evolution signals Sequence similarity Phylogenetic profiles 4.1.2. Functional Annotation Gene Ontology (GO) Pfam / InterPro domains KEGG pathways 4.1.3. Literature Mining & Text Evidence co-mention in articles NLP extraction of interactions curated knowledge bases 4.1.4. Biological Network Topology shared neighbors clustering in interaction networks pathway co-membership 4.1.5. Homology-Based Templates Predicted interactions are transferred from known complexes with homologs. These features are combined to produce a final interaction probability score. 4.2 STRING STRING (Search Tool for the Retrieval of Interacting Genes/Proteins) One of the most widely used databases for large-scale PPI predictions. Website: https://string-db.org/ Key Features Integrates multiple evidence channels: experimental data text mining co-expression genomic neighborhood gene fusion co-occurrence curated databases Interaction scores are probabilistic and evidence-weighted. Organism-wide PPI network available for hundreds of species. Input Protein name / gene ID Organism selection Output Interaction scoring matrix Network visualization Evidence breakdown Functional modules Advantages Comprehensive and easy to navigate Strong integration of heterogeneous data Suitable for global PPI network analysis Limitations Does not predict binding interface Text-mined connections may be noisy Not designed for structural predictions 4.3 PrePPI PrePPI is a hybrid sequence- and structure-informed PPI predictor. Website: https://honiglab.c2b2.columbia.edu/PrePPI/ Key Features Integrates >10 evidence types: homology-based structural templates functional annotation co-expression phylogenetic profiles domain interactions Bayesian framework combining all evidence Incorporates structural analogs even when structures are not available Input Protein pairs (ID or sequence) Output Interaction probability Contribution breakdown of each evidence type Structural template suggestions (when available) Advantages Hybrid (sequence + structure) improves accuracy High coverage for proteome-level predictions Useful for hypothesis generation Limitations Dependent on template availability No full 3D complex output (unlike docking) 4.4 PPI-Miner PPI-Miner uses literature mining (NLP) to extract PPI evidence. Website: http://caps.ncbs.res.in/ppiminer/ Key Features Extracts co-occurrences of protein names in PubMed articles Uses NLP and text-pattern heuristics Curates interaction keywords Input Gene symbol / protein name Output Ranked list of candidate PPIs Supporting literature evidence Article references Advantages Finds literature-supported interactions not present in curated DBs Can serve as complementary evidence to biochemical predictions Limitations Sensitive to text-mining noise No structural or sequence analysis Limited to proteins discussed in literature 4.5 COTH COTH (COmplex Threading and Homology modeling) predicts PPI using template-based modeling without requiring full structural docking. Website: https://zhanggroup.org/COTH/ Key Features Predicts interactions by threading sequence pairs onto known complex templates Identifies interacting domains and interface residues Assigns confidence scores (C-score) Can work even when full structures are unknown Input FASTA sequences of two proteins Output Predicted interaction confidence Interface residues Representative complex template Advantages Better structural insight compared to other sequence-only methods Does not require docking Good when homologous templates exist Limitations Template-limited Structural detail lower than docking/AlphaFold-Multimer 4.6 Comparison of Sequence / Knowledge-Based Tools Tool Type Data Sources Output Strengths Limitations STRING Integrated / knowledge-based Genomics, co-expression, text mining, experiments PPI network + scores Large-scale network; high coverage Not structural; mixed noise PrePPI Hybrid (sequence + template) Evolutionary, functional, templates Interaction probability Multi-evidence integration No complex structure PPI-Miner Literature mining PubMed articles PPI + supporting texts Finds literature-based interactions No sequence/structure use COTH Template-based Structural template DB + threading Interface prediction Provides structural hints Template availability limited 4.7 When to Use Sequence / Knowledge-Based Methods These models are best suited for: 4.7.1. Proteome-wide filtering Before expensive docking or AlphaFold-Multimer predictions. 4.7.2. Finding candidates for experimental validation STRING/PrePPI are commonly used in early discovery. 4.7.3. Supporting evidence Combine with: docking scores interface energy (PDBePISA) deep learning predictions (Chapter 5) 4.7.4. When structural data is unavailable COTH and PrePPI can still provide useful interaction hypotheses. 4.8 Integrating Knowledge-Based Tools into a Workflow A practical example: STRING → identify co-functional proteins likely to interact PrePPI / COTH → obtain structural analogs or domain-level interaction hints Docking (Chapter 2) → predict 3D complex PDBePISA (Chapter 3) → analyze interface stability AlphaFold-Multimer (Chapter 6) → generate high-confidence structures Deep Learning (Chapter 5) → cross-check sequence-level plausibility This multi-stage screening increases reliability and reduces false positives. 4.9 Summary Sequence- and knowledge-based PPI prediction methods provide broad coverage, fast inference, and useful functional context, although they lack structural specificity. They serve as essential tools for hypothesis generation and proteome-wide screening and complement both docking-based and deep learning–based predictions.

Chapter 5 Deep Learning–Based PPI Prediction 5.1 Why Deep Learning for PPI Prediction? 5.2 General Deep Learning Paradigms for PPI Prediction 5.3 D-SCRIPT 5.4 DeepPurpose (PPI Module) 5.5 MAPE-PPI 5.6 Comparison of Deep Learning Models 5.7 When to Use Deep Learning Models 5.8 Integrating Deep Learning with Other Prediction Methods 5.9 Summary

Chapter 5 Deep Learning–Based PPI Prediction Deep learning (DL) has transformed protein–protein interaction (PPI) prediction by enabling models to learn complex patterns directly from amino acid sequences or embeddings. Unlike sequence/knowledge-based models (Chapter 4), DL approaches do not rely on handcrafted features, and unlike docking methods (Chapter 2), they do not require 3D structures. This chapter introduces three representative deep learning frameworks for PPI prediction: D-SCRIPT DeepPurpose (PPI module) MAPE-PPI We also summarize the general DL paradigms used in PPI prediction and how these models complement other approaches. 5.1 Why Deep Learning for PPI Prediction? Traditional PPI prediction methods struggle to capture: high-order sequence dependencies non-linear interaction patterns co-evolutionary features hidden in raw sequences structural constraints not explicitly modeled Deep learning addresses these challenges by learning latent representations of proteins that encode biological, chemical, and evolutionary signals. Advantages of DL-based PPI prediction Requires only sequences Captures non-linear patterns automatically Scales to large datasets Compatible with pretrained protein language models Amenable to transfer learning and fine-tuning Limitations Requires substantial training data Interpretability can be low Predictions may lack structural detail Sensitive to dataset bias 5.2 General Deep Learning Paradigms for PPI Prediction Current DL-based models fall into several broad categories: Siamese / Twin Network Models Two proteins are encoded separately → embeddings concatenated → classifier predicts interaction. Used by: - D-SCRIPT - MAPE-PPI - DeepPurpose (PPI module) Graph Neural Network (GNN) Models Represent proteins as residue-level or domain-level graphs. Captures: - structural constraints - long-range interactions - co-evolution signals Transformer-Based Embedding Models Use pretrained protein language models such as: ESM ProtBERT ProtT5 MSA Transformer These embeddings feed downstream PPI classifiers. Contact Map Prediction Models Some DL tools predict residue–residue contact maps between protein pairs. Used by: - D-SCRIPT - Several co-evolution + DL hybrid models 5.3 D-SCRIPT D-SCRIPT is a highly influential DL model for predicting PPIs directly from amino acid sequences. Repository https://github.com/samsledje/D-SCRIPT Key Features Predicts both interaction probability and residue–pair contact map Uses pretrained embeddings (e.g., ESM-1b, ProtBERT) Employs a graph-like projection module to identify interface residues High interpretability compared to most DL models Model Architecture Protein embeddings from pretrained LM Dimensionality reduction & projection layers Outer product + CNN to learn pairwise residue interactions Aggregation into a final logistic output Input Two amino acid sequences (FASTA) Output Interaction probability score Optional contact map (binding interface) Advantages High interpretability Does not require structural data Suitable for organism-level PPI predictions Limitations Sensitive to domain distribution shift Sequence-only model; does not generate complex structure 5.4 DeepPurpose (PPI Module) DeepPurpose is a multimodal deep learning toolkit originally designed for drug–target interaction (DTI) prediction, but it also includes a PPI prediction module. Repository https://github.com/kexinhuang12345/DeepPurpose Key Features Multiple choices of encoders: CNN RNN Transformer Protein language model embeddings Highly modular architecture Takes two sequences as input and learns pairwise relationships Easy to train on custom datasets Input Two protein sequences Choice of encoding (e.g., CNN, Transformer) Output Interaction likelihood Advantages Flexible Easy model prototyping Suitable for benchmarking multiple encoders Limitations No structural interpretability Dependent on training dataset quality 5.5 MAPE-PPI MAPE-PPI (Multi-view Attention and Pairwise Embedding PPI predictor) integrates multiple representations of protein sequences. Repository https://github.com/LirongWu/MAPE-PPI Key Features Multi-view learning: sequence representation physiochemical descriptors predicted structure features (e.g., contact maps) Pairwise attention module captures cross-protein interactions Superior performance on many benchmark datasets Model Architecture Embedding module: multiple feature channels Multi-view attention fusion Pairwise interaction module MLP classifier Input Amino acid sequences Optional structural or physiochemical features Output PPI probability score Advantages Exploits complementary feature types Strong performance on HHRI, HopPPI, BioGRID datasets Limitations More complex architecture Harder to interpret than D-SCRIPT 5.6 Comparison of Deep Learning Models Model Input Architecture Interpretability Strengths Limitations D-SCRIPT Sequence Siamese + contact map module High Interface prediction; interpretable Slower; needs pretrained embeddings DeepPurpose (PPI) Sequence Modular CNN/RNN/Transformer Medium Easy to customize, fast prototyping No structural output MAPE-PPI Sequence (+ optional features) Multi-view + attention Medium Strong performance across datasets Complex; less interpretable 5.7 When to Use Deep Learning Models DL-based models are most appropriate for: 5.7.1. Proteome-wide screening Much faster than docking or AlphaFold-Multimer. 5.7.2. Dataset-driven tasks Especially when curated labels exist (BioGRID / DIP / STRING). 5.7.3. Supporting evidence DL models provide probability estimates that complement: docking poses (Chapter 2) interface stability analysis (Chapter 3) sequence-based predictions (Chapter 4) 5.7.4. Cases lacking structural data DL methods rely solely on sequences. 5.8 Integrating Deep Learning with Other Prediction Methods A recommended workflow: Use DL models to predict PPI probability (D-SCRIPT / DeepPurpose / MAPE-PPI) Filter high-confidence candidates → Reduces computational burden on docking or AF-M. Generate complex structures for top candidates AlphaFold-Multimer (Chapter 6) Docking methods (Chapter 2) Evaluate interface using PDBePISA (Chapter 3) Refine or redesign interactions via mutation predictions, ML-based scoring, or experimental assays. 5.9 Summary Deep learning has become a central approach in computational PPI prediction, offering significant improvements over traditional feature-based methods. Models such as D-SCRIPT, DeepPurpose, and MAPE-PPI demonstrate how rich sequence embeddings and neural architectures can uncover complex biological patterns. DL-based PPI predictors: require minimal input scale well complement structural modeling tools provide valuable interaction likelihoods However, they still lack structural mechanistic detail, which must be obtained from docking, interface analysis, or structure-generation models (Chapter 6).

Chapter 6 Structure Generation Methods: AlphaFold-Multimer 6.1 What Is AlphaFold-Multimer? 6.2 How AlphaFold-Multimer Works 6.3 Key Confidence Metrics (pLDDT, pTM, ipTM) 6.4 Predicted Aligned Error (PAE) 6.5 Evaluating AF-Multimer Predictions with DockQ 6.6 Advantages of AlphaFold-Multimer 6.7 Limitations of AlphaFold-Multimer 6.8 Integrating AF-Multimer with Docking, PISA, and Deep Learning 6.9 Recommended Best Practices 6.10 Summary

Chapter 6 Structure Generation Methods: AlphaFold-Multimer Traditional docking-based methods (Chapter 2) attempt to sample and score possible orientations between proteins using structural information. In contrast, structure-generation approaches directly produce 3D complex models from amino acid sequences, without requiring docking or predefined interface hypotheses. The most successful and widely adopted structure-generation tool for PPIs is AlphaFold-Multimer (AF-Multimer), an extension of AlphaFold2 capable of predicting protein complexes. 6.1 What Is AlphaFold-Multimer? AlphaFold-Multimer is a deep learning framework designed to predict multi-chain protein complex structures using: joint MSAs inter-chain co-evolution geometric pattern learning iterative recycling strategies AF-Multimer outputs complete 3D structural models containing all protein chains in the complex. This enables accurate prediction of binding interfaces, assembly stoichiometry, and global arrangement—something docking alone often cannot reliably achieve. 6.2 How AlphaFold-Multimer Works AF-Multimer extends the original AlphaFold2 architecture in several ways: 6.2.1. Joint MSA Construction AF-M attempts to pair homologous sequences across different species, identifying co-evolutionary signals between chains. Paired MSAs (preferred) Unpaired MSAs (fallback) Concatenation of MSAs for all chains 6.2.2. Evoformer-Multimer Blocks The Evoformer is extended to enable: cross-chain attention pair representation between chains inter-chain geometric reasoning This allows the network to infer: interface residue positions long-range inter-chain contacts the arrangement of chains in 3D space 6.2.3. Structure Module The structure module generates 3D coordinates using: invariant point attention (IPA) torsion-angle prediction iterative recycling for refinement 6.2.4. Recycling Predictions are refined by feeding outputs back into the model several times, improving global geometry and interface accuracy. 6.3 Key Confidence Metrics (pLDDT, pTM, ipTM) AlphaFold-Multimer provides several critical confidence metrics useful for assessing prediction quality: pLDDT — Local Confidence A per-residue score (0–100) indicating local structural accuracy. >90: very high local confidence 70–90: reasonable <70: unreliable local structure pTM — Predicted TM-score A global confidence metric evaluating the overall accuracy of the folded structure. ipTM — Inter-chain TM-score A unique metric for multimers that measures confidence in inter-chain geometry. ipTM is the most important indicator of whether AF-Multimer believes two proteins truly interact. > 0.6 → strong interface confidence 0.4–0.6 → uncertain interaction < 0.4 → likely non-interacting or incorrect interface Recommended composite score: 0.8 × ipTM + 0.2 × pTM Used for ranking multiple Multimer models. 6.4 Predicted Aligned Error (PAE) AF-Multimer outputs a PAE matrix describing predicted alignment error between all pairs of residues. Interpretation: Low inter-chain PAE → reliable interface High inter-chain PAE → unstable / noisy binding interface PAE is often more informative than pLDDT for multimer evaluation. 6.5 Evaluating AF-Multimer Predictions with DockQ AF-Multimer structures are commonly benchmarked using DockQ, an established metric for evaluating protein complex models. DockQ incorporates: Fnat (fraction of native contacts) LRMSD (ligand RMSD) iRMSD (interface RMSD) DockQ score interpretation: Score Quality >0.80 High-quality complex 0.50–0.80 Medium 0.23–0.50 Acceptable <0.23 Incorrect DockQ is frequently used to: benchmark AF-Multimer against docking evaluate modeled complexes compare multiple AF-M outputs 6.6 Advantages of AlphaFold-Multimer Predicts complexes directly from sequence A major advantage over docking. Often more accurate than docking Especially for obligate complexes with strong co-evolution signals. Provides residues-level interface confidence Through PAE and ipTM. Useful for protein design workflows Including: binder design enzymatic complexes de novo scaffolds RFdiffusion outputs Does not require templates or known interface information 6.7 Limitations of AlphaFold-Multimer Despite its strengths, AF-Multimer has important limitations: Limited for transient or weak interactions Such interactions often lack evolutionary signals → low ipTM. Sensitive to MSA pairing Incorrect pairing → hallucinated or incorrect interfaces. May generate biologically irrelevant assemblies Spurious compact interfaces are common. Cannot explore alternative binding modes Docking is still needed for sampling conformational diversity. Poor performance for: intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) large oligomers (>4–6 chains) systems with competing binding partners flexible multi-domain proteins Not ideal for mutation scanning Relative ΔΔG is not reliable compared to specialized energetics tools. 6.8 Integrating AF-Multimer with Docking, PISA, and Deep Learning A robust prediction workflow typically combines AF-Multimer with other methods: Step 1 — Sequence-Level Screening From Chapter 4–5: STRING PrePPI D-SCRIPT DeepPurpose MAPE-PPI → identify candidates likely to interact. Step 2 — AF-Multimer Structure Prediction Run AF-Multimer using: multiple seeds paired MSAs rank models by (0.8×ipTM + 0.2×pTM) Step 3 — Evaluate Interfaces Use: PAE ipTM pLDDT Step 4 — Complement with Docking (Chapter 2) Docking is useful when: AF-Multimer fails ipTM is low interfaces are ambiguous multiple poses are possible Use methods such as: HADDOCK HDOCK ClusPro ZDOCK Step 5 — Interface Stability with PDBePISA (Chapter 3) Evaluate: ΔGint ΔGdiss interface area H-bond networks Step 6 — Final Ranking with DockQ Select the top structural models Compare across AF-Multimer and docking predictions 6.9 Recommended Best Practices Always check ipTM and PAE, not only pLDDT Use multiple model seeds (8–20) Avoid trusting overly compact “hallucinated” complexes For weak interactions → use docking + PISA + Deep Learning voting For multi-chain systems → run subcomplexes separately Carefully curate MSAs for multimer inputs Combine AF-Multimer with docking for alternative poses 6.10 Summary AlphaFold-Multimer represents a major advance in protein complex prediction, enabling structural modeling of PPIs directly from sequences. However, its performance varies depending on interaction type, evolutionary signals, and MSA construction. To achieve reliable PPI modeling, AF-Multimer must be used in conjunction with: docking (Chapter 2) interface analysis (Chapter 3) sequence- or deep-learning predictors (Chapters 4–5) A hybrid workflow remains the most robust approach for accurate structural PPI prediction.
